search_results.lyrics:
Seventeen Lyrics[Verse 1]

Feelings make me anxious so I keep them inside
It's a straight line to normalcy kid

So I walk home and listen to music
Too dumb to notice that I couldn't choose it

[Chorus]

So I'm trying to be that person that I could have been
And, no I can't complain with all the things I've seen
Do you think that nothing lasts forever?
[Verse 2]
Perfect curls and summer dresses
Waking up at 7, making sure I'd impress him
Passing tests with flying colors
Spending time at home while friends were under the covers

[Chorus]
Everything was lame when I was 17
So I'm trying to be that person that I could have been
And, no I can't complain with all the things I've seen
Do you think that nothing lasts forever?

[Outro]
You'd think , you'd think, that it will last forever
Now I'm 23, still feel like a teen
Now I'm 23, still feel like a teen
Now I'm 23, still feel like a teen
Now I'm 23, still feel like a teenYou might also like1Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Seventeen” by Haley Blais on Genius
song.title: Seventeen

album.full_title: Let Yourself Go - EP by Haley Blais
album.name: Let Yourself Go - EP

annotations:
And, no I can’t complain with all the things I’ve seen
 Do you think that nothing lasts forever?

In her retrospective analysis of her teenage days, she starts to see the circumstances and events in her life that sculpted her to be who she is today . Her current state is probably not how she pictured it to be at 17. But looking back at things, she’s come to terms and is somewhat content with who she’s become.

So I walk home and listen to music
 Too dumb to notice that I couldn’t choose it
Represents how many during their teenage years feel like they can’t listen to the music they want to and how they feel forced to listen to whatever is popular.
Now I’m 23, still feel like a teen
We think the passage of time will make us feel more grown up. But the confusion and anxiety and insecurity that we tie to our teenage years can follow us long after.
Feelings make me anxious so I keep them inside
Classic pubescent urges to keep things pent up inside.
Funny girl is never the bride
This is about the trope where the funny girl is a side character; a token space to pull laughs from the audience. She isn’t her own person, so she doesn’t need a love interest.

Headbands, and thick eyeliner
 Teenage romance with a vampire
Weird fashion trends, scene makeup, twilight. High school things for high school years.

Everything was lame when I was 17
 So I’m trying to be that person that I could have been

The essence of your teenage years: everything feels lame, done, whatever. You don’t care. That’s not anybody’s fault, but there are things and times that pass you by almost without your notice because you didn’t feel like paying attention. Here, Haley is trying to pay attention; to have what she could have had and to be who she could have been if she cared more.

description.plain: Coolest fucking bitch in town, released as Blais' first 2022 single, is a song about two people growing up and beginning to make their way into adulthood, whilst navigating the depression and “growing pains” that comes with that.

song.embed_content: Read “Coolest fucking bitch in town” by Haley Blais on Genius
song.full_title: Coolest fucking bitch in town by Haley Blais
song.title: Coolest fucking bitch in town

annotatable.link_title: Coolest fucking bitch in town by Haley Blais
annotatable.title: Coolest fucking bitch in town

body.plain: Coolest fucking bitch in town, released as Blais' first 2022 single, is a song about two people growing up and beginning to make their way into adulthood, whilst navigating the depression and “growing pains” that comes with that.

annotations:
You want to drink a drink that’s watered down
 It’ll just take you longer

“It’ll just take you longer” is referencing that trying to drink something thats watered down is futile–it won’t stop them from getting drunk as they will just keep drinking more drinks to get there.

She’s criticising them for the idiocy of this act, as it is not doing anything but wasting time for them to drink diluted alcohol as they won’t stop regardless. This is exposing her hypocrisy, and her own struggles with this sort of behaviour, as she does the same thing by going all the way to the office of a therapist but not bothering to actually attend the meeting.
But you wonder what’ll happen Christmas Day

Christmas Day is synonymous with family, and celebrating joyously with said family.

Although the person is happy for their mother getting married, that doesn’t mean that they feel as if their mother’s partner is a part of their family, and they don’t feel comfortable with this new change; yet another example of the theme of change in adulthood.

Crying in the backseat of your parent’s car
 You said that you don’t have a curfew anymore

A curfew is a traditional source of annoyance for teenagers worldwide, as they want to be free to do what they want. Blais juxtaposes the usual excitement of not having a curfew anymore with the person crying about it.

The curfew is thus symbolising the safety and control that being a kid provides, and now that the person is a adult they’re crying about the fact that being free and independent isn’t all its thought up to be.

album.full_title: Below the Salt by Haley Blais
album.name: Below the Salt

annotatable.link_title: Be Your Own Muse by Haley Blais
annotatable.title: Be Your Own Muse

annotations: I guess sometimes you just have to be your own muse

When asked by Lithium Magazine what Blais defines as “being your own muse”, she replied that

Being your own muse is just the simplest mantra. “Be Your Own Muse” is probably one of the oldest songs on the album. I wrote it in 2017, so this album is kind of a time capsule of the last few years. It really stemmed from a lot of loneliness and trying to be okay with that. Also, not having the drive to change. Just feeding off of that pain. Everyone’s tortured and you write your best songs in that state.

annotations: Call me a liar, I’ve heard it before

By inviting the listener to “call her liar” and saying she’s already heard it before, Haley makes a direct reference to her first single “Too Good” from her debut LP Below the Salt in which she sings the same phase.

description.plain: The title of this song likely comes from the ransom letter written to JonBenet Ramsey’s parents in connection with her murder, which mentions the status of the note-writer as “members of a small foreign faction.”

song.embed_content: Read “Small Foreign Faction” by Haley Blais on Genius
song.full_title: Small Foreign Faction by Haley Blais
song.title: Small Foreign Faction

album.full_title: Let Yourself Go - EP by Haley Blais
album.name: Let Yourself Go - EP

annotatable.link_title: Small Foreign Faction by Haley Blais
annotatable.title: Small Foreign Faction

body.plain: The title of this song likely comes from the ransom letter written to JonBenet Ramsey’s parents in connection with her murder, which mentions the status of the note-writer as “members of a small foreign faction.”

annotations:
I’m just a foreign faction
 Irreconcilable conflict at parties
 I feel like a chain reaction
 But sadly I don’t know how it started

After the second verse, this verse can also be interpreted another way. Reading the narrator as the same true crime fan: they become the foreign faction, bringing up these cold case crimes at (literal) parties, starting a chain reaction among friends who form opinions and debate about what could have happened. Nonetheless, at the end of it all, the crimes remain unsolved.

Listening to a church choir
 Sing some hymns about someone

Ultimately those who become fascinated with these true crime stories are just outsiders looking in. Communities and families will mourn the victims but they will always be just “someone” to the onlookers.

I like to sit around fires
 And catch the embers on my tongue

The second verse adds another layer to the narration and pokes at what it even means to be a “true crime fan.” Fire represents the crimes the narrator is fascinated by and the embers are the emotions the crimes illicit. Perhaps these crimes can outrage, horrify, disgust, and sadden but ultimately the embers won’t burn as the narrator is not directly involved.

I never wanted anything and
 I never got it

The chorus cleverly splits the two popular opinions surrounding Ramsey’s death. The ransom note demanded money from the Ramsey family for her safe return. If the killers were the family, they would have never actually wanted the money. If the killers were intruders, they never ended up getting the money.

I feel like a chain reaction
 But sadly I don’t know how it started
While Ramsey’s death was so infamous and reached so many people, we ultimately still don’t know the true original circumstances (the start of it all) that caused her death.

I’m just a foreign faction
 Irreconcilable conflict at parties

This song was inspired by the infamous JonBenét Ramsey murder case. A ransom note was left for the family where the kidnappers referred to themselves as “individuals that represent a small foreign faction.” Due to the Ramsey’s fame as a child beauty pageant star, the case sparked worldwide interest, discussion, debates and theories on what happened. Many people were split between the intruder theory— some “foreign faction” entered the home—while others believed that the family killed Ramsey and everything was staged. In this verse, the narrator is the crime itself or the perpetrators (of which we have no personal connections to), which has entered the public’s psyche and caused debate and “irreconcilable conflict at parties.”

description.plain: In ‘Let Yourself Go’, Blais makes a stabbing statement about the throw-away comments people make concerning one’s outward appearence and it’s relation to social success. Blais sarcastically remarks about how easy it is to be happy, that the way to success is not through internal fullfillment or self-esteem, but through outward appearence and the social rewards that come with looking ‘put-together’.

song.embed_content: Read “Let Yourself Go” by Haley Blais on Genius
song.full_title: Let Yourself Go by Haley Blais
song.title: Let Yourself Go

album.full_title: Let Yourself Go - EP by Haley Blais
album.name: Let Yourself Go - EP

annotatable.link_title: Let Yourself Go by Haley Blais
annotatable.title: Let Yourself Go

body.plain: In ‘Let Yourself Go’, Blais makes a stabbing statement about the throw-away comments people make concerning one’s outward appearence and it’s relation to social success. Blais sarcastically remarks about how easy it is to be happy, that the way to success is not through internal fullfillment or self-esteem, but through outward appearence and the social rewards that come with looking ‘put-together’.

annotations: You’re so pretty when you smile
More patronising, throw-away comments that Blais makes to reduce the subject of the song to someone who simply has to look ‘good’ in order to have everything they want.
To look like your internal vacation

the contrast of ‘look’ suggesting exterior, and ‘internal’ suggesting interior further emphasises that Blais is focusing on appearence, and not how the subject is feeling or thinking or coping with life. the goal is to seem as though you are put together.  The focus is on the superficial. this is mentioned in a vlog Blais uploaded to youtube(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_xVgkVeS9k), whereby, when addressing her S.A.D., she states that ‘[Iwant to make it] look like i’ve got my shit together- not make it look like, make it //feel// like i’ve got my shit together. Because I don’t care what it looks like to people’
It’s a simple operation
suggests something unnatural and artifical about the process of getting yourself together
You should know...

Suggests that somehow Blais is helping the subject by informing them that they have ‘let themself go’ indicating the warped idea that telling someone they are paying less attention to their outward appearence is a useful thing, because they can then ‘fix’ themselves.

It’s no wonder you’re alone now
 When they used to break your door down

Here, Blais is blaming the person’s lack of a partner on the fact that they have ‘let themselves go’. It touches on how we often see human value from their relationship status, and that in order to be a valued human in a relationship, we need to present ourselves in an traditionally attractive way.

‘they used to break your door down’ further highlights that the subject onced was ‘together’ and that they now are not, suggesting that they have in some way decreased in social value or have become inferior.

If you want it, you can have it
 You can reach out and just grab it
 If you’re ready, you can take it
 You should know...

‘if you want it, you can have it’ is an example of a throw away comment concerning the seemingly simple procedure of getting what you want. This song is a sarcastic remark at how people feel as though they are being helpful by commenting on someone’s ‘lack’ of physical and social self-care.
